text:
Recap: Lecture 7 âª

What we covered last time:

Marginal Rate of Substitution (MRS): the rate at which a consumer trades \(x_2\) for \(x_1\) along an indifference curve
Utility functions: assign numbers to bundles so that \(U(A) > U(B) \iff A \succ B\)
Utility maximization: the optimal bundle is where the budget line is tangent to the highest indifference curve

\[MRS = \frac{MU_1}{MU_2} = \frac{p_1}{p_2}\]
Today: What happens to the optimal choice when \(p_1\) changes? ğŸ‘‰ This gives us the demand curve!

title: Consumer Theory
text:
The Key Idea ğŸ’¡


From Optimization to Demand
When we change the price of good 1 (\(p_1\)) while holding income (\(M\)) and \(p_2\) fixed, the optimal quantity of \(x_1\) changes. Tracing these optimal quantities gives us the individual demand curve.

The experiment:

Fix \(M\) and \(p_2\)
Start with some price \(p_1\), find the optimal \(x_1^*\)
Increase \(p_1\) â¡ï¸ budget line pivots inward â¡ï¸ new, lower \(x_1^*\)
Decrease \(p_1\) â¡ï¸ budget line pivots outward â¡ï¸ new, higher \(x_1^*\)
Plot all \((x_1^*, p_1)\) pairs â¡ï¸ individual demand curve

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Deriving Individual Demand: Graphically ğŸ“‰













Upper panel (indifference curve diagram):
As \(p_1\) rises from 10 to 30, the budget line pivots inward (steeper).
The tangency points A, B, C trace the price-consumption curve.
The optimal quantity \(x_1^*\) falls: \(6 \to 4 \to 2\).
Below we plot just \((x_1^*, p_1)\) â¬‡ï¸

title: Consumer Theory
text:
The Individual Demand Curve ğŸ“‰













Reading the demand curve:
Each point shows the optimal quantity at a given price.

At \(p_1 = 10\): consumer buys \(x_1^* = 6\)
At \(p_1 = 15\): consumer buys \(x_1^* = 4\)
At \(p_1 = 30\): consumer buys \(x_1^* = 2\)


The Demand Curve
Shows the quantity a consumer is willing and able to buy at each price, ceteris paribus (holding everything else constant).

title: Consumer Theory
text:
The Law of Demand ğŸ“œ


Law of Demand
As the price of a good rises, the quantity demanded falls (and vice versa), ceteris paribus.

Why does it hold? Two effects when \(p_1\) rises:


ğŸ’° Income effect
Higher price makes the consumer effectively poorer â¡ï¸ buys less of most goods

â†”ï¸ï¸ Substitution effect
Higher price makes good 1 relatively more expensive â¡ï¸ consumer switches to good 2

ğŸ’¡ For normal goods, both effects work in the same direction â¡ï¸ demand curves slope downward.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Reserve Price ğŸ·ï¸


Reserve (Reservation) Price
The highest price a consumer is willing to pay for a good or service. Equivalently, it measures the benefit of obtaining the good.

Decision rule: Buy if \(\text{Price} \leq \text{Reserve Price}\)
Tourism example âœˆï¸:
A touristâ€™s reserve price for a sunset boat tour in Lagos might be â‚¬45. If the tour costs â‚¬35, they buy it and enjoy a â€œsurplusâ€ of â‚¬10. If it costs â‚¬55, they skip it.

ğŸ‘‰ The demand curve can be read as a curve of reserve prices â€” at each quantity, it tells us the maximum someone would pay for that unit.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Why a Kink? ğŸ¤”

The market demand curve can have a kink when different consumers have different maximum willingness to pay (choke prices).


Below â‚¬4: Both A and B buy
\(Q_{Market} = Q_A + Q_B = 10 - 2P\)
Above â‚¬4: Only A buys (Bâ€™s demand is zero)
\(Q_{Market} = Q_A = 6 - P\)

In practice (large markets):
With thousands of consumers, individual kinks smooth out â¡ï¸ market demand curves are typically smooth.
ğŸ’¡ For this course, weâ€™ll usually work with linear market demand curves (no kinks) for simplicity.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
The Linear Demand Equation ğŸ“


Linear Demand â€” Inverse Form
\[P = b + mQ\]
where \(P\) is price, \(Q\) is quantity demanded, \(b\) is the vertical intercept (choke price), and \(m\) is the slope (\(m < 0\)).

Interpreting the parameters:

\(b\) = the maximum price anyone would pay (quantity = 0). Also called the choke price.
\(m\) = \(\frac{\Delta P}{\Delta Q}\) (negative!) â€” how much price falls per additional unit demanded
The horizontal intercept = \(-b/m\) = the quantity demanded when price is zero

text:
Example: Canned Tuna Market ğŸ¥«













The data (adapted from Lecture Notes available in Canvas):
\(b = 6\) (choke price = â‚¬6)
Slope: \(m = \frac{\Delta P}{\Delta Q} = \frac{-1}{2000}\)
Equation:
\[P = -\frac{1}{2000}Q + 6\]
Verify: At \(Q = 2000\):
\(P = -\frac{1}{2000}(2000) + 6 = 5\) âœ…
At \(Q = 4000\):
\(P = -\frac{1}{2000}(4000) + 6 = 4\) âœ…

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Finding Quantity from Price

Often we want the direct demand form â€” quantity as a function of price.
Starting from the inverse demand: \(P = b + mQ\)
\[Q = \frac{P - b}{m}\]
Canned tuna example:
\[P = -\frac{1}{2000}Q + 6 \quad \Longrightarrow \quad Q = -2000P + 12000 = 12000 - 2000P\]
Verify: At \(P = 3\): \(Q = 12000 - 2000(3) = 6000\) cans/month âœ…
ğŸ‘‰ Both forms are equivalent â€” use whichever is more convenient for the problem!

title: Consumer Theory
section: Total Expenditure and Total Revenue ğŸ’¸
text:
Total Expenditure and Total Revenue ğŸ’¸


Total Expenditure = Total Revenue
\[TE = TR = P \times Q\]
What consumers spend equals what sellers receive.

Example: If \(P = 3\) and \(Q = 6000\):
\[TE = TR = 3 \times 6000 = â‚¬18{,}000 \text{ per month}\]
Graphically, \(P \times Q\) is the area of the rectangle under the price line, from 0 to \(Q\).
ğŸ‘‰ The relationship between price changes and total revenue depends on elasticity (Lecture 9!).

title: Consumer Theory
section: Change in Quantity Demanded vs.Â Change in Demand âš ï¸
text:
Change in Quantity Demanded vs.Â Change in Demand âš ï¸

This is one of the most important distinctions in economics!


â†•ï¸ Movement Along the Curve
A change in quantity demanded caused by a change in the goodâ€™s own price.
The curve itself does not move.
Example: Hotel room price drops from â‚¬100 to â‚¬80 â¡ï¸ more rooms demanded.

â†”ï¸ï¸ Shift of the Curve
A change in demand caused by a change in anything other than own price.
The entire curve moves left or right.
Example: A viral TikTok video about Lisbon â¡ï¸ demand for Lisbon hotels shifts right at every price.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Determinants of Demand (Shift Factors) âš™ï¸

Factors that shift the demand curve (right = increase, left = decrease):


â¡ï¸ Increase in demand:

ğŸ“‰ Price of complements falls (e.g.Â flights cheaper â¡ï¸ more hotel demand)
ğŸ“ˆ Price of substitutes rises (e.g.Â Airbnb raises fees â¡ï¸ more hotel demand)
ğŸ’° Income rises (normal goods)
â¤ï¸ Preferences shift toward the good
ğŸ‘¥ Population of buyers grows


â¬…ï¸ Decrease in demand:

ğŸ“ˆ Price of complements rises
ğŸ“‰ Price of substitutes falls
ğŸ“‰ Income falls (normal goods)
ğŸ’” Preferences shift away
ğŸ“‰ Population of buyers shrinks


âš ï¸ A change in own price is a movement along the curve, never a shift!

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Consumer Surplus â­


Consumer Surplus (CS)
The difference between what consumers are willing to pay (reserve price) and what they actually pay (market price). Graphically, it is the area below the demand curve and above the price line.













For a linear demand:
\[CS = \frac{1}{2} \times Q^* \times (b - P^*)\]
where \(b\) is the choke price.
Example: \(b = 10\), \(P^* = 4\), \(Q^* = 6\):
\[CS = \frac{1}{2}(6)(10 - 4) = â‚¬18\]

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Why Consumer Surplus Matters ğŸ’¡

Consumer surplus measures the net benefit consumers get from participating in the market.


Applications in tourism:

ğŸ« Dynamic pricing (airlines, hotels) aims to capture consumer surplus
ğŸ›ï¸ Government tourist taxes reduce consumer surplus
ğŸ Promotional offers increase consumer surplus to attract visitors


Policy implications:

CS helps measure the welfare effects of price changes, taxes, or subsidies
A higher CS means consumers are better off
Weâ€™ll use CS again when studying market equilibrium and market efficiency

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Tourism Demand in Practice âœˆï¸

How does this theory apply to tourism?


Individual demand for travel:
Each tourist has a reservation price for a trip â€” shaped by income, preferences, time constraints.
ğŸ“‰ As flight prices rise, fewer tourists travel (law of demand).
ğŸ’° As income grows, tourists demand more and higher-quality travel (normal good).

Market demand for a destination:
The sum of all potential touristsâ€™ for a given price.
Shifts when:

ğŸŒ Exchange rates change (â‚¬ strengthens â¡ï¸ more outbound tourism)
ğŸ“± Viral social media exposure
âš ï¸ Safety concerns or natural disasters
âœˆï¸ New direct flights to the destination


ğŸ’¡ The concepts of demand shifts and consumer surplus help tourism managers set optimal prices!

Summary ğŸ“‹

Todayâ€™s Key Takeaways:

Individual demand is derived from utility maximization as price changes

Movement along (own price change) vs.Â Shift (other factors change)

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice

Question: If the price of Airbnb accommodation falls significantly, what happens to the demand curve for hotel rooms?
A. The demand curve for hotels shifts to the right
B. The demand curve for hotels shifts to the left
C. There is a movement along the hotel demand curve
D. The demand curve for hotels becomes steeper


Answer: B

Airbnb is a substitute for hotels. When the price of a substitute falls, demand for the good decreases (shifts left). Consumers switch from hotels to the now-cheaper Airbnb. This is a shift (not a movement along), because itâ€™s a change in the price of another good.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice

Question: The market demand for guided tours in Sintra is \(P = 50 - 2Q\) (â‚¬ per tour). At a price of â‚¬20, what is the consumer surplus?
A. â‚¬112.50
B. â‚¬500
C. â‚¬300
D. â‚¬225


Answer: D

At \(P = 20\): \(20 = 50 - 2Q \Rightarrow 2Q = 30 \Rightarrow Q = 15\) tours.
\[CS = \frac{1}{2} \times Q^* \times (b - P^*) = \frac{1}{2} \times 15 \times (50 - 20) = \frac{1}{2} \times 15 \times 30 = â‚¬225\]
ğŸ‘‰ The triangle has base \(Q^* = 15\) and height \((b - P^*) = 30\).

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question âœï¸

Suppose the Algarve hotel market has two types of tourists:

Domestic tourists (Portugal): Individual demand \(P = 200 - 4Q_D\)
International tourists: Individual demand \(P = 300 - 2Q_I\)

There are 100 domestic tourists and 50 international tourists. Assume all tourists of the same type are identical.
a) Write the market demand for each group of tourists.
b) Derive the total market demand curve for the Algarve hotel market.
c) At a price of â‚¬100 per night, how many rooms are demanded by each group? What is total market demand?
d) Calculate the consumer surplus for each group at \(P = â‚¬100\).
e) A new low-cost airline begins flights to Faro, reducing travel costs for international tourists. How would this affect the total market demand curve? Explain whether this is a movement along or a shift of demand.

title: Consumer Theory
section: Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts a & b
text:
Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts a & b

a) Market demand for each group:
Domestic (100 identical tourists): \(Q_D^{total} = 100 \times Q_D = 100 \times \frac{200 - P}{4} = \frac{100(200 - P)}{4} = 5000 - 25P\) for \(P \leq 200\)
International (50 identical tourists): \(Q_I^{total} = 50 \times Q_I = 50 \times \frac{300 - P}{2} = \frac{50(300 - P)}{2} = 7500 - 25P\) for \(P \leq 300\)
b) Total market demand (horizontal sum):
For \(P \leq 200\) (both groups buy): \(Q_{Total} = (5000 - 25P) + (7500 - 25P) = 12500 - 50P\)
For \(200 < P \leq 300\) (only international): \(Q_{Total} = 7500 - 25P\)
For \(P > 300\): \(Q_{Total} = 0\)

title: Consumer Theory
section: Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts c & d
text:
Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts c & d

c) At P = â‚¬100 (both groups are active since \(100 < 200\)):
\(Q_D^{total} = 5000 - 25(100) = 2500\) rooms
\(Q_I^{total} = 7500 - 25(100) = 5000\) rooms
\(Q_{Total} = 2500 + 5000 = 7500\) rooms âœ… (matches \(12500 - 50(100) = 7500\))
d) Consumer surplus at P = â‚¬100:
Domestic: Inverse demand: \(P = 200 - \frac{Q_D^{total}}{25}\). Choke price = 200. \(Q^* = 2500\).
\[CS_D = \frac{1}{2} \times 2500 \times (200 - 100) = \frac{1}{2} \times 2500 \times 100 = â‚¬125{,}000\]
International: Inverse demand: \(P = 300 - \frac{Q_I^{total}}{25}\). Choke price = 300. \(Q^* = 5000\).
\[CS_I = \frac{1}{2} \times 5000 \times (300 - 100) = \frac{1}{2} \times 5000 \times 200 = â‚¬500{,}000\]
Total CS = â‚¬125,000 + â‚¬500,000 = â‚¬625,000

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 3: Solution â€” Part e

e) New low-cost airline to Faro:
This reduces the total cost of visiting the Algarve for international tourists (complementary good: transport + accommodation).
Effect: The demand curve for international tourists shifts to the right. At every price, international tourists now demand more hotel rooms.
This is a shift of the demand curve, not a movement along it, because the change is caused by a factor other than the hotelâ€™s own price (namely, a fall in the price of a complementary good â€” flights).
On the graph: The total market demand curve shifts right. The segment for \(200 < P \leq 300\) shifts right (international demand increases), and the segment for \(P \leq 200\) also shifts right (the international component is now larger at every price).
The domestic demand curve is unaffected (they donâ€™t fly to Faro from within Portugal).

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Why Elasticity Matters ğŸ“ˆ


The Revenue Problem
A hotel wants to increase revenue. Should it raise or lower prices? The answer depends on how responsive tourists are to price changes!

Two scenarios:


Scenario A: âœˆï¸ Flights from Lisbon to Paris
Price increases 10% â†’ Bookings drop 25%
ğŸ‘‰ Passengers are very sensitive to price
Revenue falls when price rises!

Scenario B: ğŸ”Œ Hotel electricity
Price increases 10% â†’ Usage drops 2%
ğŸ‘‰ Hotels barely respond to price
Revenue rises when price rises!


Elasticity measures this price sensitivity precisely. Essential for pricing, taxation, and policy!

title: Consumer Theory
section: What Is Price Elasticity of Demand? ğŸ“
text:
What Is Price Elasticity of Demand? ğŸ“


Price Elasticity of Demand (PED or \(\varepsilon_d\))
The percentage change in quantity demanded when price changes by 1%, ceteris paribus.
\[\varepsilon_d = \frac{\% \Delta Q}{\% \Delta P} = \frac{\Delta Q / Q}{\Delta P / P}=\frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta P}\frac{P}{Q}\]

Key properties:

\(\varepsilon_d\) is almost always negative (law of demand: \(\uparrow P \Rightarrow \downarrow Q\))
We often report the absolute value: \(|\varepsilon_d|\)
Itâ€™s unit-free: same whether measuring in euros or dollars, trips or thousands of trips

Example: If \(\varepsilon_d = -2\), then a 1% increase in price causes a 2% decrease in quantity demanded.
ğŸ’¡ Elasticity tells us the proportional response, not the absolute change!

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Elastic vs.Â Inelastic Demand âš–ï¸

We classify demand based on \(|\varepsilon_d|\):









Category
Condition
Interpretation
Example




Perfectly Inelastic
\(\|\varepsilon_d\| = 0\)
Quantity doesnâ€™t change at all
Life-saving medicine


Inelastic
\(0 < \|\varepsilon_d\| < 1\)
Quantity changes less than price
Gasoline (short run)


Unit Elastic
\(\|\varepsilon_d\| = 1\)
Quantity changes equally with price
Some textbooks estimate for housing


Elastic
\(\|\varepsilon_d\| > 1\)
Quantity changes more than price
Restaurant meals, tourism


Perfectly Elastic
\(\|\varepsilon_d\| = \infty\)
Any price increase â†’ demand drops to zero
Competitive market goods



Key insight: If \(|\varepsilon_d| > 1\) (elastic), consumers are very responsive. If \(|\varepsilon_d| < 1\) (inelastic), they are not very responsive.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Visualizing Elasticity ğŸ“‰













Visual intuition:
Inelastic demand (red):

Steeper curve
Quantity barely responds to price
\(|\varepsilon_d| < 1\)

Elastic demand (black):

Flatter curve
Quantity responds a lot to price
\(|\varepsilon_d| > 1\)

âš ï¸ Careful: Steepness depends on units! Elasticity is the proper measure.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Two Methods of Calculation ğŸ”¢

Method 1: Point Elasticity (at a specific point on the demand curve)
\[\varepsilon_d = \frac{dQ}{dP} \cdot \frac{P}{Q}\]

Use when you have a demand function and want elasticity at a particular \((P, Q)\)
For linear demand \(Q = a - bP\) \(\Rightarrow\) \(\frac{dQ}{dP} = -b\)

Method 2: Arc Elasticity (between two points)
\[\varepsilon_d = \frac{\Delta Q / Q_{avg}}{\Delta P / P_{avg}} = \frac{\frac{Q_2 - Q_1}{(Q_1 + Q_2)/2}}{ \frac{P_2 - P_1}{(P_1 + P_2)/2}}\]

Use when you observe two discrete points (e.g., before/after price change)
Uses midpoints to avoid asymmetry issues (increasing 10% \(\neq\) decreasing 10%)

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Example 1: Point Elasticity âœï¸

Demand for hotel rooms in Porto: \(Q = 500 - 2P\) (rooms per night, \(P\) in â‚¬)
Question: What is the price elasticity of demand when \(P = â‚¬100\)?

. . .

Solution:

Find \(Q\) at \(P = 100\): \(Q = 500 - 2(100) = 300\) rooms
Calculate \(\frac{dQ}{dP}\): For \(Q = 500 - 2P\), we have \(\frac{dQ}{dP} = -2\)
Apply formula: \[\varepsilon_d = \frac{dQ}{dP} \cdot \frac{P}{Q} = (-2) \cdot \frac{100}{300} = -\frac{200}{300} = -0.67\]

Interpretation: At \(P = â‚¬100\), demand is inelastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| = 0.67 < 1\)). A 1% price increase causes only a 0.67% decrease in quantity demanded.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Example 2: Arc Elasticity âœï¸

A museum in Sintra raises ticket prices from â‚¬10 to â‚¬12. Visitors fall from 1,000/day to 800/day.
Question: What is the arc elasticity of demand?

. . .

Solution:
\[\varepsilon_d = \frac{Q_2 - Q_1}{(Q_1 + Q_2)/2} \div \frac{P_2 - P_1}{(P_1 + P_2)/2}\]
\[= \frac{800 - 1000}{(1000 + 800)/2} \div \frac{12 - 10}{(10 + 12)/2}\]
\[= \frac{-200}{900} \div \frac{2}{11} = -\frac{200}{900} \cdot \frac{11}{2} = -\frac{2200}{1800} \approx -1.22\]
Interpretation: Demand is elastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| = 1.22 > 1\)). A 1% price increase causes a 1.22% decrease in visitors.

title: Consumer Theory
section: Elasticity Along a Linear Demand Curve ğŸ“
text:
Elasticity Along a Linear Demand Curve ğŸ“













Key insight: For a linear demand curve, elasticity varies along the curve!
Why? \(\varepsilon_d = \frac{dQ}{dP} \cdot \frac{P}{Q}\)

Slope \(\frac{dQ}{dP}\) is constant
But ratio \(\frac{P}{Q}\) changes

Three regions:

Top (high \(P\), low \(Q\)): \(|\varepsilon_d| > 1\) (elastic)
Middle (midpoint): \(|\varepsilon_d| = 1\) (unit elastic)
Bottom (low \(P\), high \(Q\)): \(|\varepsilon_d| < 1\) (inelastic)

ğŸ’¡ The same demand curve is elastic at some prices, inelastic at others!

title: Consumer Theory
section: What Makes Demand More Elastic? ğŸ¤”
text:
What Makes Demand More Elastic? ğŸ¤”

Five key determinants:

Availability of substitutes ğŸ”„

More/closer substitutes â†’ more elastic
Example: Brand-name hotels (many alternatives) vs.Â only hotel in remote village

Share of budget ğŸ’°

Larger expense â†’ more elastic
Example: International vacation vs.Â coffee

Necessity vs.Â luxury ğŸ’

Luxuries â†’ more elastic; Necessities â†’ less elastic
Example: Business travel (necessity) vs.Â leisure tourism (luxury)






Time horizon ğŸ•

Long run â†’ more elastic (more time to adjust)
Example: After fuel price increase, tourists eventually switch to closer destinations

Definition of the market ğŸ—ºï¸

Narrowly defined â†’ more elastic
Example: â€œTAP flights to Parisâ€ (elastic) vs.Â â€œall flights to Parisâ€ (less elastic) vs.Â â€œall air travelâ€ (even less elastic)


Summary: Demand is more elastic when consumers have options, time, and the good is less essential.

Tourism Examples âœˆï¸



Inelastic Tourism Demand:
1ï¸âƒ£ Business travel: Fixed meetings, little flexibility â†’ \(|\varepsilon_d| \approx 0.3\)

4ï¸âƒ£ Unique destinations (e.g., GalÃ¡pagos): No close substitutes

Elastic Tourism Demand:

4ï¸âƒ£ All-inclusive packages: Many competing offers


ğŸ’¡ Tourism managers must understand their marketâ€™s elasticity to price optimally!

title: Consumer Theory
text:
The Revenue Test ğŸ’°


Total Revenue and Elasticity
Total Revenue: \(TR = P \times Q\)
When price changes:

If demand is elastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| > 1\)): Price and revenue move in opposite directions
If demand is inelastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| < 1\)): Price and revenue move in the same direction
If demand is unit elastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| = 1\)): Revenue is maximized


Why?

Elastic: \(\%\Delta Q > \%\Delta P\) â†’ quantity effect dominates
Inelastic: \(\%\Delta Q < \%\Delta P\) â†’ price effect dominates

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Cross-Price Elasticity ğŸ”„


Cross-Price Elasticity of Demand
Measures how quantity demanded of good \(i\) responds to a price change in good \(j\):
\[\varepsilon_{ij} = \frac{\% \Delta Q_i}{\% \Delta P_j} = \frac{\Delta Q_i / Q_i}{\Delta P_j / P_j}\]

Interpretation:

\(\varepsilon_{ij} > 0\): Goods \(i\) and \(j\) are substitutes (e.g., flights vs.Â trains)
\(\varepsilon_{ij} < 0\): Goods \(i\) and \(j\) are complements (e.g., flights and hotels)
\(\varepsilon_{ij} = 0\): Goods are independent (e.g., milk and concert tickets)

Example: If \(\varepsilon_{\text{hotels, flights}} = -0.4\), a 10% increase in flight prices causes 4% decrease in hotel demand.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Income Elasticity ğŸ’°


Income Elasticity of Demand
Measures how quantity demanded responds to income changes:
\[\varepsilon_M = \frac{\% \Delta Q}{\% \Delta M} = \frac{\Delta Q / Q}{\Delta M / M}\]

Interpretation:

\(\varepsilon_M > 1\): Luxury good (tourism, fine dining)
\(0 < \varepsilon_M < 1\): Normal good (most goods)
\(\varepsilon_M < 0\): Inferior good (budget accommodations, bus travel)

Tourism application: International tourism has high income elasticity (\(\varepsilon_M \approx 1.5 - 2.5\)). During recessions, tourism demand falls sharply!

Summary ğŸ“‹

Todayâ€™s Key Takeaways:

Price elasticity of demand (\(\varepsilon_d\)): percentage change in quantity per 1% price change
Elastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| > 1\)): quantity very responsive; Inelastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| < 1\)): not very responsive
Calculation: Point formula \(\varepsilon_d = \frac{dQ}{dP} \cdot \frac{P}{Q}\) or arc formula (midpoint method)
Determinants: substitutes, budget share, necessity vs.Â luxury, time, market definition
Revenue: If elastic, price â†‘ â†’ revenue â†“; If inelastic, price â†‘ â†’ revenue â†‘; Maximized at \(|\varepsilon_d| = 1\)
Other elasticities: cross-price (substitutes/complements), income (normal/inferior/luxury)
Tourism applications: dynamic pricing, tax incidence, demand forecasting

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice

Question: The demand for luxury cruises from Lisbon is estimated to have a price elasticity of \(\varepsilon_d = -2.5\). If cruise operators raise prices by 8%, what happens to total revenue?
A. Total revenue increases
B. Total revenue decreases
C. Total revenue stays constant
D. Cannot determine without knowing the initial price


Answer: B

Demand is elastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| = 2.5 > 1\)), so price and revenue move in opposite directions. An 8% price increase causes approximately \(-2.5 \times 8\% = -20\%\) decrease in quantity. Since quantity falls more than price rises, total revenue decreases.
This is the revenue test: elastic demand â†’ price â†‘ â†’ revenue â†“.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice

Question: Airbnb and traditional hotels are substitutes. If the cross-price elasticity between Airbnb and hotels is \(\varepsilon_{AH} = 0.8\), and Airbnb prices increase by 10%, what happens to hotel demand?
A. Hotel demand increases by 8%
B. Hotel demand decreases by 8%
C. Hotel demand increases by 10%
D. Hotel demand increases by 1.25%


Answer: A

Cross-price elasticity formula: \(\varepsilon_{AH} = \frac{\% \Delta Q_{\text{hotels}}}{\% \Delta P_{\text{Airbnb}}}\)
\[0.8 = \frac{\% \Delta Q_{\text{hotels}}}{10\%} \Rightarrow \% \Delta Q_{\text{hotels}} = 0.8 \times 10\% = 8\%\]
Since \(\varepsilon_{AH} > 0\) (substitutes), when Airbnb price rises, hotel demand increases by 8%.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question âœï¸

The Algarve Tourism Authority is studying demand for beach resorts. They have the following demand function:
\[Q = 10{,}000 - 20P\]
where \(Q\) is the number of tourists per month and \(P\) is the average price per night (in â‚¬).
a) Calculate the price elasticity of demand when \(P = â‚¬100\).
b) Is demand elastic or inelastic at this price? What does this mean for revenue if resorts raise prices?
c) At what price is demand unit elastic (\(|\varepsilon_d| = 1\))? What is the quantity demanded and total revenue at this price?
d) The income elasticity for Algarve tourism is estimated at \(\varepsilon_M = 1.8\). If European incomes rise by 5% next year, by what percentage will demand for Algarve tourism increase?

title: Consumer Theory
section: Exercise 3: Solution for Parts a & b
text:
Exercise 3: Solution for Parts a & b

a) Price elasticity at P = â‚¬100:
Demand: \(Q = 10{,}000 - 20P\)
At \(P = 100\): \(Q = 10{,}000 - 20(100) = 8{,}000\) tourists
Calculate elasticity: \(\varepsilon_d = \frac{dQ}{dP} \cdot \frac{P}{Q}\)
\[\frac{dQ}{dP} = -20\]
\[\varepsilon_d = (-20) \cdot \frac{100}{8000} = -\frac{2000}{8000} = -0.25\]
b) Elastic or inelastic?
\(|\varepsilon_d| = 0.25 < 1\) â†’ Demand is inelastic at \(P = â‚¬100\).
Revenue implication: Since demand is inelastic, price and revenue move in the same direction. If resorts raise prices, total revenue will increase. Quantity falls, but by a smaller percentage than price rises, so \(TR = P \times Q\) increases.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 3: Solution for Part c

c) Unit elastic demand (\(|\varepsilon_d| = 1\)):
For linear demand \(Q = 10{,}000 - 20P\) (or inverse: \(P = 500 - 0.05Q\)), unit elasticity occurs at the midpoint.
Method 1 (midpoint of inverse demand):
Choke price (intercept): \(P = 500\) when \(Q = 0\)
Maximum quantity: \(Q = 10{,}000\) when \(P = 0\)
Midpoint: \(P^* = \frac{500}{2} = â‚¬250\), \(Q^* = \frac{10{,}000}{2} = 5{,}000\) tourists
Verify: \(\varepsilon_d = (-20) \cdot \frac{250}{5000} = -\frac{5000}{5000} = -1\) âœ“
Total Revenue at unit elasticity:
\[TR = P^* \times Q^* = 250 \times 5{,}000 = â‚¬1{,}250{,}000\]
This is the maximum possible revenue on this demand curve!

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 3: Solution for Parts d

d) Income elasticity:
\(\varepsilon_M = 1.8\) means a 1% increase in income causes a 1.8% increase in demand.
If incomes rise by 5%:
\[\% \Delta Q = \varepsilon_M \times \% \Delta M = 1.8 \times 5\% = 9\%\]
Demand for Algarve tourism will increase by 9%.
ğŸ’¡ Since \(\varepsilon_M > 1\), tourism is a luxury good, highly responsive to income changes!

This lecture completes the Consumer Theory module by introducing elasticity as a crucial tool for understanding demand responsiveness. Students should grasp that elasticity is a unit-free measure that allows comparison across markets and is essential for revenue management, taxation analysis, and policy design. The revenue test (elastic demand â†’ price and revenue move opposite; inelastic â†’ same direction) is particularly important for business applications. Emphasize that tourism generally has high price elasticity (especially leisure travel), making the industry vulnerable to economic shocks but also responsive to pricing strategies.
